The second half of the season was never going to be easy, Barcelona are still loaded with comfortable players that have suffered in training since Setien came in charge, and the coach still has a lot of problems to fix with this team. We should expect a trophy-less season, it was happening either way and I prefer it to happen with a coach that can build a new team rather than one that was finishing to destroy the old one.

The first hour vs Valencia was awful, very similar to the first half of the Spanish Cup final vs the same opponent. Pointless possession, no penetration or width and no shots on goal on open play. Things got a lot better in the second half, but it was already too late.

Frenkie and Arthur were really poor today. Frenkie made all the wrong decisions he rarely does; the Brazilian still looks sluggish and off form. Busquets wasn't at his best either. Slow, predictable and aimless, a day to forget to most of the midfield.

Messi needed to receive the ball a lot more, but his decisions on the ball weren't as perfect as they always are. Ansu plain bad and Griezmann had to spend most of the game defending, again.

Vidal's impact was incredible the moment he came on, exceptional player and success this season will depend a lot on the Chilean.

The result on pitch was bad, but what happened before the match off pitch was worse. Barcelona sent another La Masia player away to Juventus and brought another mediocre Brazilian from Juventus in his place for €8m. This was done this way to camouflage the club's books like the Cillessen-Neto operation.

Shameful movements by the board to hide the financial difficulties they're sinking Barcelona. We have Messi and a great coach in charge now, but we can expect a few years of disappointment coming soon...

Ruud Gullit (ex-Milan & Netherlands): "Frenkie is one of those who touches the ball from here to there, but without much sense. There is much talk about how great Frenkie doesn’t play in Barça and I have my doubts. Really, I think he can do much better." [voetbal primeur via md]

Gullit: "He comes, gets the ball, makes a feint, then passes left or right, nothing else happens. I only say this because I know he can do better. Frenkie has to play better. He is the ideal son-in-law, everything is great, but for now I have not seen it."

Gullit: "I want to give him confidence, because it’s wonderful to see him with the ball. But I look at the result, if the passes are wide and wide, it’s no use. And there are times when he really is like that."
